Secondary ion mass spectrometry

Secondary-ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) is a technique used to analyze the composition of solid surfaces and thin films by sputtering the surface of the specimen with a focused primary ion beam and collecting and analyzing ejected secondary ions. The mass/charge ratios of these secondary ions are measured with a mass spectrometer to determine the elemental, isotopic, or molecular composition of the surface to a depth of 1 to 2 nm.

With over 70 years worth of experience cumulatively in the analytical services industry, we have worked with our customers to bring the highest quality analysis to research teams across the globe.

Benefits of Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry:

  • Inherent sputtering of layered structures
  • Excellent detection sensitivity (ppm-ppm) for dopants, impurities
  • Can detect all elements and isotopes, including H
  • Depth profiling dopants and impurities in III-V heterostructures
  • Surface, layer, substrate and interface
  • Stoichiometry in some cases

Applications of SIMS:

  • Routine implants analysis
  • High Precision Analysis (<1%)
  • SOI analysis
  • Advance sample preparation
  • Small area analysis – devices
  • EPI Layer analysis
